I tried going into the ATen code and trying to figure this out but it is little steep for me. I would hope that the issue lies in the in-place operation torch._standard_gamma() rather than Tensor.expand() since that might be a larger problem

The code below is enough to recreate the problem:

concentration = torch.tensor([[2.3126, 0.8453]]).expand([2, 1, 2])
print(torch._standard_gamma(concentration))
print(torch._standard_gamma(concentration.clone()))

# tensor([[[7.1208e-01, 3.6902e-01]],
#         [[1.1755e-38, 1.1755e-38]]])
# tensor([[[1.4383, 0.5455]],
#         [[3.3665, 0.1593]]])

Note that the problem only occurs when there is at least one dimension with length 1

@fritzo Do you have any good ideas? I can try to assist but this dive is quickly becoming quite deep for an amateur in the inner workings of pytorch

I tried going into the ATen code and trying to figure this out but it is little steep for me. I would hope that the issue lies in the in-place operation `torch._standard_gamma()` rather than `Tensor.expand()` since that might be a larger problem

The code below is enough to recreate the problem:
```
concentration = torch.tensor([[2.3126, 0.8453]]).expand([2, 1, 2])
print(torch._standard_gamma(concentration))
print(torch._standard_gamma(concentration.clone()))

# tensor([[[7.1208e-01, 3.6902e-01]],
#         [[1.1755e-38, 1.1755e-38]]])
# tensor([[[1.4383, 0.5455]],
#         [[3.3665, 0.1593]]])
```
Note that the problem only occurs when there is at least one dimension with length 1

@fritzo Do you have any good ideas? I can try to assist but this dive is quickly becoming quite deep for an amateur in the inner workings of pytorch
